== The Decision ==
== The Decision ==
Line 82: Line 82:
The decision that implemented ''Brown'', called [http://www.law.cornell.edu/supct/html/historics/USSC_CR_0349_0294_ZO.html|''Brown II''], did not use the term "segregation" anymore. Instead it addressed "discrimination" only. This change puzzled and dismayed Black's clerk, but Black would not explain it to him.<ref>John Q. Barrett, Supreme Court Law Clerksâ Recollections of Brown v. Board of Education II, 79 St. JOHNâS U. L. REV. 823, 866 (2006).</ref> One explanation is that the justices, particularly the senior justice Black, were concerned with making "anti-segregation" precedent in ''Brown''. That way later they could rely on ''Brown'' in a case involving parochial schools. But ''Brown II'' would probably not be precedent, only targeting the specific people named in ''Brown''. So the justices were free to use the narrower term "discrimination."<ref>Glenna Goldis, "The Catholic Scare: How Anti-Catholic Prejudice Shaped Brown v. Board" 29â30. Available at SSRN: http://ssrn.com/abstract=1084764</ref>

Instead it addressed "discrimination" only. This change puzzled and dismayed Black's clerk, but Black would not explain it to him.<ref>John Q. Barrett, Supreme Court Law Clerksâ Recollections of Brown v. Board of Education II, 79 St. JOHNâS U. L. REV. 823, 866 (2006).</ref> One explanation is that the justices, particularly the senior justice Black, were concerned with making "anti-segregation" precedent in ''Brown''. That way later they could rely on ''Brown'' in a case involving parochial schools. But ''Brown II'' would probably not be precedent, only targeting the specific people named in ''Brown''. However, note that it is difficult to discern Black's motivations because before he died he asked his son to burn all of his conference notes and Court papers.<ref>BERNARD SCHWARTZ, SUPER CHIEF 80 (New York University Press 1983).</ref> nhjkfhvkBk gusegf
